Award.AwardTitle: ATOL: Assembling a taxonomically balanced genome-scale reconstruction of the evolutionary history of the Enterobacteriaceae
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to determine the evolutionary relationships among the Enterobacteria. Enterobacteria are a diverse family of bacteria that occupy a wide variety of environments including both plant and animal hosts, and many are biomedically or agriculturally relevant. Genome sequences of members of this family are abundant, but are almost exclusively limited to a small number of species associated with human diseases. This project will sequence the genomes of 100 additional previously neglected species, and use these data to reconstruct the phylogeny of the group.

Evolutionary analysis of bacteria and some other groups of organisms is complicated by their ability to exchange genetic material between species, which causes inference of conflicting relationships between different regions of the genomes. To tackle this problem, a multidisciplinary team of biologists, statisticians and computer scientists will develop new methods of analysis. These new approaches will allow resolution of the relationships between nearly all regions of enterobacterial genomes, and provide tools for other researchers studying different groups. In addition, development of educational modules will allow incorporation of this work into the training of undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Wisconsin, and beyond. A public database will be created to encourage use of these genome sequences by any interested party.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past twenty years, genome sequencing has made an enormous impact on our understanding of how bacteria evolve. The first comparisons of bacterial genomes in the early 2000’s revealed that many species have historically and continue to exchange DNA with other species and strains of bacteria. The net result is that different parts of the genome have different evolutionary histories.  The impact is that it can be challenging to understand the relationship among organisms, genes, and traits of interest.  This in turn can have practical implications for identification of bacteria in agricultural, clinical and environmental surveillance efforts.

This project resulted in a detailed dissection of the evolution of bacterial genomes of enterobacteria. The family, formally called Enterobacteriaceae, includes both pathogens and common residents of healthy hosts as varied as plants and animals, as well as free-living environmental organisms. We compared the genomes of over 300 enterobacteria. To ensure our analyses covered the full breadth of diversity of the family we sequenced genomes of unrepresented species.  A total of 106 distinct named species were included in the final project dataset. From these data, we reconstructed a robust evolutionary framework, or species tree, that is useful as an underlying model for understanding trait evolution (host-range shifts, spread of antibiotic resistance, etc.). These high-quality reference genomes and phylogeny are a useful resource for microbiome studies.  We also developed methods and software to detect horizontal gene transfer events between ancestral lineages.  Application of these demonstrated far more extensive gene exchanges between particular subsets of enterobacteria than previously recognized.

This project also had broader impacts for a variety of groups. Undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral scientists were trained in computational biology, statistics, microbiology, evolutionary biology, genomics and educational outreach through participation in this project. Software and methods developed for phylogenetic analysis are freely available for use by other researchers. Project data is actively being used by other researchers, including one group developing diagnostic assays for detection and identification of agricultural pathogens. The project also included a strong outreach component targeted at K-12 students and educators. This included development of two novel reusable curriculum resources and a substantial update of a third, for teaching high school and middle school students about phylogenetic analysis and DNA sequence evolution. These were presented at three teacher workshops at UW-Madison, three times at the annual Wisconsin Society of Science Teachers conference, and the materials are freely available for teachers through the J.F. Crow Institute for the Study of Evolution web site. In addition, three novel activities about microbes and evolution were developed for younger learners and presented at outreach events at UW-Madison and four local elementary schools.
